questions.question_text: Which is the maximum number of samples that can be submitted to WildFire per day, based on a WildFire subscription?

discussion.content:
answer is 1000 however its not listed in the choices, I assume option A is a typo error it should be 1000 not 10,000..if it is, correct answer is A.

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire/9-0/wildfire-admin/submit-files-for-wildfire-analysis/manually-upload-files-to-the-wildfire-portal.html#:~:text=All%20Palo%20Alto%20Networks%20customers,a%20day%20for%20WildFire%20analysis.
They messed up the question. Clearly they meant automatic verdict queries, instead of submitted samples. That would be 10,000.

Selected Answer: A
Answer is 1000

Actually... D is the only answer that fits. Total daily submissions for standard Wildfire is 150. There are two problems with including the query limits of 1050: a) 150 + 1050 != 1,000. b) The question specifically asks for "submissions."
The only Wildfire limit that matches one of these numbers is D, 5,000. Prisma Cloud Compute limits daily Wildfire submissions to exactly 5,000.
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire/u-v/wildfire-api/about-the-wildfire-api/wildfire-api-access-control/impose-api-limits
The answer is 1000, As part of the WildFire subscription, you can submit up to 150 sample submissions and up to 1,050 sample queries a day.

This information has changed!!!
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire/10-0/wildfire-admin/wildfire-overview/wildfire-subscription

Selected Answer: A
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire/10-2/wildfire-admin/wildfire-overview/wildfire-subscription
From version 8.1 onwards「you can submit up to 150 sample submissions and up to 1,050 sample queries a day.」
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire/10-1/wildfire-admin/wildfire-overview/wildfire-subscription.html - "The WildFire API supports up to 1,000 file submissions and up to 10,000 queries a day."
A. 10,000 submissions 1,000 API queries
1000 per day --

Yeah, seems like a mistake in answer options:
"The WildFire API supports up to 1,000 file submissions and up to 10,000 queries a day."
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire/9-0/wildfire-admin/wildfire-overview/wildfire-subscription

A and C

Active/Active— Both firewalls in the pair are active and processing traffic and work synchronously to handle session setup and session ownership. Both firewalls individually maintain session tables and routing tables and synchronize to each other. Active/active HA is supported in virtual wire and Layer 3 deployments.
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/8-1/pan-os-admin/high-availability/ha-concepts/ha-modes

Selected Answer: AC
A and C correct

Selected Answer: AC
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-admin/high-availability/ha-concepts/ha-modes
AC... https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/8-1/pan-os-admin/high-availability/ha-concepts/ha-modes#:~:text=Active%2Fpassive%20HA%20is%20supported,such%20as%20IPSec%20security%20associations.

questions.question_text: In which two types of deployment is active/active HA configuration supported? (Choose two.)
For which two reasons would a firewall discard a packet as part of the packet flow sequence? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
A and B

Denying traffic will discard the packet. Packets can also be discarded due to malformed or incorrect frames, datagrams or packets. 

C and D are irrelevant as packets would never be discarded if allowed and ECMP simply allows the use of multiple routes or paths to a destination. 

Read up on "Packer Flow Sequence", it details where exactly it will discard packets (layer 2, layer 3 and on)
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClVHCA0

Selected Answer: AB
A and B correct

Selected Answer: AB
A and B only suitable answers
common sense question a and b

questions.question_text: Which logs enable a firewall administrator to determine whether a session was decrypted?

discussion.content:
A is the answer and not C.

Yes in PAN-OS 10 the Decryption Log was introduced but that is more suited for troubleshooting where decryption broke the SSL/TLS session. It is far easier to check if a session was decrypted by checking the Traffic Log. 

It is clear here in the PAN-OS 10 Admin guide, section "Verify Decryption", that to check the Traffic Log to verify if decryption happened. Silly enough it also states in the very same document that you can check the decryption log (but, it seems to miss out that only for decryption failures).
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-0/pan-os-admin/decryption/verify-decryption.html

Here is the link for Decryption Log, you will read that it only logs unsuccessful decryption attempts. 
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-0/pan-os-admin/decryption/troubleshoot-and-monitor-decryption/decryption-logs.html#idb1b7e4a6-b48c-4ca7-8569-b785da780dd6

Now I am not running PAN-OS 10 in the real world so I can't say 100% but reading off the documentation, that is how I would answer the question.

comments.content: This is true. Answer is C. The new exam is evaluating version. 10.0

A
You missed the key word, whether or not it was decrypted. Decryption log is used for troubleshooting if decryption was busted, NOT whether or not something was decrypted.

discussion.content:
As of, August 17th, the Palo Alto Networks Certified Network Security Engineer (PCNSE) and the Palo Alto Networks Certified Network Security Administrator (PCNSA) certification exams reflect changes based on PAN-OS 10.0. Correct Answer is C
https://live.paloaltonetworks.com/t5/certification-articles/pcnse-and-pcnsa-exam-changes-with-10-0/ta-p/344832

Selected Answer: C
I work with PAN OS 10 and 11, the decryption log has both successful and failed decryption logs.
Old question, probably before there even were Decryption logs. I'd still put Traffic though, just because you can filter by Decrypted column really easy.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
I think A, because it say "whether a session was decrypted". Decryption log is for traffic is already decrypted, but in Traffic log you can see if the traffic is decrypted or not.

Selected Answer: C
C not A on 10.2 and 11.0

Selected Answer: A
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-admin/decryption/verify-decryption

Selected Answer: A
Although the newer version have dedicate log type for "Decryption", as others already pointed out, those logs can be used to troubleshoot decryption/negotiations issues. The question is asking how you can determine if session was decrypted - the best way to is still to check the details of the traffic log and see if the flag "decrypted" is checked.

In addition, according to documentations by default only the unsuccessful decryption handshakes will be logged under "Decryption", which means if session is successfully decrypted, no log will be shown here and you might think that session was not decrypted.

Selected Answer: A
Traffic log can show status of decryption or not first.

Selected Answer: A
If a security rule is logging it will always show if it was decrypted (and is the simplest thing to look at). By default, the decryption rules log only on unsuccessful SSL handshakes. If you're troubleshooting, this is the log to go look at but if all you want to do is figure out decrypted yes/no, traffic log even in 10.0+.

Selected Answer: C
There is now a decryption log: https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-1/pan-os-admin/decryption/troubleshoot-and-monitor-decryption/decryption-logs.html

comments.content: Per reading the document Monitor>Logs>Traffic traffic logs seems to be right after all, i change to answer A.

discussion.content:
A is correct: Decryption logs are dependent on traffic logs being enabled. 
PAN-OS 10 doc cited here:
The Decryption log learns each session’s App-ID from the Traffic log, so Traffic logs must be enabled to see the App-ID in the Decryption log. If Traffic logs are disabled, the App-ID shows as incomplete.
The exam is based in panos 9.1 as far as I know, so answer should be A.

Please keep in mind, the PCNSE 9 exam focuses only on PANOS 9.1
Answer = A
Question is simply asking which log shows whether a session was decrypted.

Palo Alto introduces questions on the new version when it gets to the X.1.
So since now it is 10.0 the exam focuses on the 9.1 version, so correct answer is A, for the time being.
Answer is A. There´s no thing as Decryption log.

comments.content:
Ans is C
The Decryption Log (Monitor
Logs
Decryption
) provides comprehensive information about sessions that match a Decryption policy to help you gain context about that traffic so you can accurately and easily diagnose and resolve decryption issues. The firewall does not log traffic if the traffic does not match a Decryption policy.
Correct, but starting Version 10, there IS a 'decryption log'. PA should fix this question.

discussion.content:
v10 answer is C

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-0/pan-os-admin/decryption/troubleshoot-and-monitor-decryption/decryption-logs.html

questions.question_text:
An administrator needs to upgrade an NGFW to the most current version of PAN-OSֲ® software. The following is occurring:
✑ Firewall has internet connectivity through e 1/1.
✑ Default security rules and security rules allowing all SSL and web-browsing traffic to and from any zone.
✑ Service route is configured, sourcing update traffic from e1/1.
✑ A communication error appears in the System logs when updates are performed.
✑ Download does not complete.
What must be configured to enable the firewall to download the current version of PAN-OS software?

comments.content: https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-1/pan-os-upgrade/upgrade-pan-os/pan-os-upgrade-checklist#id53a2bc2b-f86e-4ee5-93d7-b06aff837a00
The main reason it is not be is that Updates happen through mgmt palne.. mgmt plane does not use security policies
The question literally describes a service route, so it goes through the data plane.

discussion.content:
D:

A cant be, there is no static service route to point to "palo alto updates" question is regarding that there is existing internet connection, so, default route should exist, 

B: security policy allowing SSL traffic already exist so there is access from any to any

C: there is no scheduler involved on errors recurring with communication,

D: is the most closer to the issue, so D is correct.
The Default security rules and security rules allowing all SSL and web-browsing traffic to and from any zone. covers that (B is wrong) correct ans = D

Selected Answer: D
You have the default rules which will allow intrazone traffic for any app. So the issue could be that DNS cannot resolve correctly the update server.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct.

Selected Answer: D
The key word is default rule.

Selected Answer: D
D

It's NOT B because the security rules already exist any to any zone for SSL
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
It is between B or D:
B. Interface is facing the Internet directly, so it would be intranet (allowed by default)
D. It is needed to be configured in order to translate PA URL into IP addresses

So, D is correct

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D

Selected Answer: D
B is wrong because of the default ruleset being in use, so the intrazone rule allows paloalto-updates app. D is correct as "generic communication error" on updates is usually a DNS issue

Selected Answer: D
Given that question mentions about the communication error, D is the most appropriate answer. If the policy was denying it, the logs will mention traffic dropped/denied due to a configured policy rule or lack of a policy rule.

I believe D is the answer because the updates must be downloaded from the "updates.paloaltonetworks.com" site, the firewall must have DNS configured to take advantage of this. As DNS configuration was not mentioned during the question preface, I concluded that DNS must not have been configured.

Selected Answer: D
DNS Resolution: When the firewall attempts to download updates or software, it needs to resolve domain names to IP addresses to reach the update servers. If there's an issue with DNS resolution, it can lead to communication errors and incomplete downloads.

The other options (A, B, and C) do not directly address the issue of DNS resolution. While static routes, security policies, and scheduled downloads may be important for overall firewall configuration, they are not the primary factor for resolving domain names to IP addresses during the update process.

Selected Answer: D
D, as per discussion shared by others here.

B: is covered, so this is not the answer because SSL and Web browsing is allowed. 
Also, https://applipedia.paloaltonetworks.com/ confirms that paloalto-updates would not give us any more access because : Implicit use Applications: ssl, web-browsing
Had this question a few weeks ago on the exam... July 2023. I'm going with D.

Selected Answer: B
Palo Alto requires their update APPIDs to be allowed, this is not mentioned in the question.

The communication error and incomplete download of updates suggest that the firewall is unable to resolve the update server's hostname to its IP address. To resolve this issue, the firewall needs proper DNS settings configured. By providing DNS settings, the firewall will be able to perform hostname resolution and establish connectivity with the update servers to download the PAN-OS software.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct.

Palo alto updates are recognized with App-ID "paloalto-updates", which makes implicit use of ssl and web-browsing. Creating a Security Policy with the proper App-ID will solve the download issue.

It is not a DNS issue, as "the download does not complete" implies a communication to be in place (then blocked due to App-ID mismatch) and proper name resolution to be succesful.

Selected Answer: B
Not dns. If it started then Dns worked. Palo does have 10+ app id for their saas upgrades etc

Selected Answer: D
The Answer is D. You must be able to resolve updates.paloaltonetworks.com from the CLI and in order to do that, you must have DNS setup under Device > Setup > Services. The easiest thing to do is point to 8.8.8.8 if you don't have an internal DNS server.

Selected Answer: B
You need dns and app id. Bad question as dns setup was not passed on

Selected Answer: D
I change my answer and agree with Spydog

Selected Answer: B
I think B is the correct answer here
Having looked at the paloalto-updates application (v10.2) its showing that it uses Standard Ports: 
tcp/443,28443

It also states "the download does not complete" which imo means that its started but failing and it would not start if there was a DNS issue.

Still unsure though

It's gotta be D.
The application paloalto-updates includes ports 443 (ssl) and 28443(only used to download software from Panorama. In this scenario, software updates are being downloaded from the Internet.) So the existing rule with SSL and web browsing should be enough.
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClkuCAC

Selected Answer: B
Application "paloalto-updates" needs to be allowed for PaloALto Updates! This is clear.
"ssl" & "web-browsing" wouldn't be enough.

The question is what "all ssl and web-browsing" means here.

B

It appears that the firewall has internet connectivity and a service route is configured, but there is an issue with downloading the current version of PAN-OS software. The problem is likely related to the firewall's security rules, as it is not allowing the necessary traffic for the update process to complete. By creating a security policy rule that allows the "PaloAlto-updates" application, the firewall will be able to connect to the update servers and download the current version of the software. Other options like static route or scheduler for timed downloads of PAN-OS software might also help but most likely security rule is the root cause.
Correct answer is D
B is the correct answer. As Paloalto application needs to be allowed.

Selected Answer: D
Agree with rammsdoct

comments.content: Also it happened to me the first time I configured my palo. Its always dns.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Correct Answer is definately D
The only other possible answer would be B, but you need to read the question carefully. It says "default rules AND rules allowing SSL and web-browsing". This traffic will be intra-zone and default intra-zone rule will allow any application on any port. So yes, firewall detect traffic as paloalto-update and will not match the rule for SSL, but will be allowed by the default rule. So the only possible option is DNS not configured properly

comments.content: Your explanation makes a lot of sense

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
BD is most likely but why such issue will log to system log, not traffic log?

Selected Answer: A
It's easier to use the traffic log to see if traffic was decrypted or not. Just look at the column decrypted which says yes or no.
The decryption log is more useful if you know it was decrypted but there was some kind or error or you need other information which are not in the traffic log

So I agree to A

Selected Answer: B
Like networkingXIV said, even when not decrypted it is *not* detected as web-browsing or ssl but paloalto-updates.

Selected Answer: D
Answer: D
As of the 1.3.2022 the pdf still shows a wrong answer. It's most definitely D. Had the same issue on my privat palo.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

The answer is D.
 "The following is occuring:
 - a communication error in the System Logs ..."
In the System Logs only failed DNS resolution can appear from that options.

comments.content:
Why would this traffic hit the default intrazone rule? The traffic is trust-untrust so it would hit the default INTERzone rule which action is DENY.

If the updates traffic with or without decryption enabled shows as "paloalto-upadtes" then the traffic is being denied by the interzone default rule and a security policy with "paloalto-updates" action allow must be created.

Traffic will definately be intra-zone for untrust-untrust. This is because the traffic is sourced by the firewall. When you are configuring the service route to point to the dataplane interface eth1/1 you need to choose which ip will be used as source, which is the IP assigned on the egress interface you choose for this service route. Since the source IP is assigned to the untrust zone and the destination is in untrust zone (following default route) traffic will be intra-zone for untrust zone and if no explicit rules, it will match the default intra-zone which by default is allowing any application on any port.

Well, I change my answer to D.

Update traffic would hit the default intrazone rule since traffic is sourced from e1/1 and egressing e1/1. Default intrazone rule has the application set to 'any', so there is no need to specify 'paloalto-updates' as the application.

Answer B is wrong. Most suitable answer is D.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Answer is B.

I'm leaning towards B. If you check the firewall logs for traffic going to 'updates.paloaltonetworks.com', you will see that the application is identified as 'paloalto-updates'. It means that this traffic would not hit the rules with the applications 'ssl' or 'web-browsing'.

Answer is B.

I'm leaning towards B. If you check the firewall logs for traffic going to 'updates.paloaltonetworks.com', you will see that the application is identified as 'paloalto-updates'. It means that this traffic would not hit the rules with the applications 'ssl' or 'web-browsing'.

comments.content:
Well, I change my answer to D.

Update traffic would hit the default intrazone rule since traffic is sourced from e1/1 and egressing e1/1. Default intrazone rule has the application set to 'any', so there is no need to specify 'paloalto-updates' as the application.

Answer B is wrong. Most suitable answer is D.

discussion.content: I believe that it is D. I just verified in my lab by removing the DNS entries under the services tab and the following error showed up in the system logs after attempting a download. 'Failed to check Antivirus content upgrade info due to generic communication error" The question specifically mentions a communication error in the logs, and that the download didn't complete not that the log message used the word complete. The question should have said that the download didn't occur. Again, Palo Alto seems more intent on tricking candidates as opposed to testing their actual knowledge.
B -- application "paloalto-updates" need to be enabled under the security policy .. Download doesn't complete, means DNS resolution happens and donwload started but couldn't complete

comments.content: No, download haven't started because it need first to resolve the FQDN and get the IP to which it needs to establish connection and start the download. In the question it mentioned that you see system log for "generic communication error", which means firewall cannot establish the connection to start the download.

discussion.content: Though I have to admit umpteen time when I have gotten the communication error when going to Palo update site when I have forgotten to setup dns servers, maybe they just have worded the question in a confusing way, Internet access is configured from security and NATing perspective whether it is working or not we do not know so I would choose D. Bad question though!

If firewall has internet connectivity via e1/1 then it implies that dns is configured! So D is out, however the as e1/1 is in internet/outside zone and it is going for updates to Palo alto that will be untrust/outside zone and intarzone default rule should take care of this so B is also not the answer! So, the question is confusing! If one were to pick the likely most plausible answer then it could be D but is not right, the DNS has to be working if Internet access is working.
Support D, a communication error means that the FW at least tired to access the download. If blocked by any policy, there should be a deny log not error.
B - correct answer. Check Q#112 clarifies it.

I'm was between B and D like everyone else. Just performed this exact scenario (without decrypting) on my PA-220 to verify if the App-ID is actually SSL. It shows up as paloalto-updates when downloading a PAN-OS update meaning that B is the correct answer for sure. paloalto-updates App-ID MUST be included in the security rule.

A. Static route pointing application PaloAlto-updates to the update servers
 ✑ Service route is configured, sourcing update traffic from e1/1. problem solved
B. Security policy rule allowing PaloAlto-updates as the application
 ✑ Default security rules and security rules allowing all SSL and web-browsing traffic to and from any zone. what I can find on PA website is tcp/53 and ssl/443 is required ports
C. Scheduler for timed downloads of PAN-OS software
 scheduling a download has no impact whatsoever on a communication error, unless its a bw issue and you schedule for off peak hours 
D. DNS settings for the firewall to use for resolution
 if a new deployment yes then dns would need to be configured, if an existing deployment then you would think that dns is already configured. the question doesnt state
 
 really a stupid question, should have more info

comments.content:
Answer = D
When Service Routes are changed, Explicit policies are required in the security rules to log and allow traffic. Which would allude to B being the correct answer...
HOWEVER, the communication error in the system logs is the key to the answer. If it was just a missing App-ID in a Security Policy, you wouldn't receive a communication error. A is obviously wrong, and C is possible because the same communication error, but D makes more sense.
The First Step in the Resolution of Communication Error =
Verify the firewall has DNS servers configured to be able to resolve updates.paloaltonetworks.com:
From the WebGUI: Go to Device > Setup > Services:
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClkuCAC

discussion.content:
Ans is C.
E1/1 is external interface so no need security policy for update.
DNS could be not a problem because the question states the "download does not complete". If it is "download does not start" then DNS must be the reason. 
The update could be failed if the schedule are close together
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClhyCAC

D is correct, 
It could be "B" if they specify that the policy has decryption.

D is correct Answer.

B it can't be as they say SSL is already allowed.
paloalto-updates App-ID supports tcp/443,28443 and 28443 is used for FW-PAN communication. More than this paloalto-updates app-id has Implicit use Applications:
ssl.
https://applipedia.paloaltonetworks.com/

comments.content:
Hi, the is exactly the reason to confirm that B is he answer: 1) they say that only ssl + web browsing are allowed. When you configure an external interface service route you need to have policies with palo alto updates App id's (which have additional ports than ssl and web browsing) 
Also a ref with pan10:https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-0/pan-os-admin/getting-started/integrate-the-firewall-into-your-management-network/set-up-network-access-for-external-services.html

Also remember traffic is originated using a service route from data plane interface. This is local generated traffic and does not require a security policy.
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClU6CAK

"f the Service Route is bound to the external interface, the connection is simply allowed to connect to the Palo Alto Networks cloud services without requiring further configuration of the security policy."

Answer D still stands as best option here in my opinion
Also, you can state the dns is working because they say the update didn't COMPLETE. So it started, so it has dns.

discussion.content:
I am still confused between B and D.
Note: Download does not COMPLETE. ( its NOT download doesnt start) which could indicate DNS is ok. 

leaning towards B.

comments.content:
Forgot link:
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClU6CAK

discussion.content:
As stated here: "If the Service Route is bound to the external interface, the services are allowed to connect to their respective Palo Alto Networks cloud services without requiring further configuration of the security policy. If the Service Route is bound to the external interface, the connection is simply allowed to connect to the Palo Alto Networks cloud services without requiring further configuration of the security policy."
So answer is D, if you can't translate updates.paloaltonetworks.com to IP the download fails.

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-0/pan-os-admin/getting-started/integrate-the-firewall-into-your-management-network/set-up-network-access-for-external-services.html

Also looking at the app-id paloalto-updates it uses another port besides 443.
Standard Ports: tcp/443,28443

discussion.content: b, not D IF THE dnS IS not configured. Palo will not be able to check updates

I vote B.
Question states that "security rules allowing all SSL and web-browsing traffic" SSL and web-browsing is not services names, it`s AppIDs. Palo Alto Updates would require paloalto-updates AppID. Also I doubt that DNS problem would generate comms issue.

Answer is D.

No need for any security rules since updates traffic is intrazone and allowed by default, which discards B and has nothing to do with SSL being allowed or not.
D is the correct answer

comments.content: I agree that B is the correct answer at the question provide the following:"Firewall has internet connectivity through e 1/1" Also the FW is allowing SSL so that means that the FW is able to reach its DNS server to resolve a URL. Just application SSL being allowed will not be sufficient to allow the upgrade.
except that, if you do not configure the DNS, the firewall won't know how to resolve the address for the updates. So D seems the correct answer.

discussion.content: B is the correct answer

choices.A: Static route pointing application PaloAlto-updates to the update servers
choices.B: Security policy rule allowing PaloAlto-updates as the application
choices.D: DNS settings for the firewall to use for resolution
choices.C: Scheduler for timed downloads of PAN-OS software
